AI - Types - ANI: Artificial Narrow Intelligence. ANI is also referred to as Narrow AI or Weak AI. Also known as weak AI, ANI is not able to learn beyond its programmed capabilities. This type of artificial intelligence is one that focuses primarily on one single narrow task, with a limited range of abilities. If you think of an example of AI that exists in our lives right now, it is ANI. This is the only type out of the three that is currently around. This includes all kinds of Natural Language or Siri.
AI - Types - AGI: Artificial General Intelligence AGI technology would be on the level of a human mind. Due to this fact, it will probably be some time before we truly grasp AGI, as we still don’t know all there is to know about the human brain itself. However, in concept at least, AGI would be able to think on the same level as a human, much like Sonny the robot in I-Robot featuring Will Smith.
AI - Types - ASI: Artificial Super Intelligence This is where it gets a little theoretical and a touch scary. ASI refers to AI technology that will match and then surpass the human mind. To be classed as an ASI, the technology would have to be more capable than a human in every single way possible. Not only could these AI things carry out tasks, but they would even be capable of having emotions and relationships.
ML - 1980: Machine learning (ML) is a subset of artificial intelligence (AI) that focuses on teaching computers and machines to replicate human learning processes, enabling them to enhance their performance over time. To do this, they use algorithms and statistical models to analyze and understand hidden patterns in datasets.
ML - Supervised: Supervised learning is the most widely used type of machine learning. It involves training a model on a labeled dataset, which means that each training example is paired with an output label. The model learns to predict the output from the input data.
ML - Supervised - Classification: Classification tasks involve predicting a discrete label. For instance, determining whether an email is spam or not, or classifying a handwritten digit from 0–9.
ML - Supervised - Classification - Logis: Despite its name, logistic regression is used for binary classification problems. It predicts the probability that a given input belongs to a certain class.
ML - Supervised - Classification - Decis: A decision tree uses a tree-like model of decisions and their possible consequences. It splits the data into subsets based on the value of input features.
ML - Supervised - Classification - Rando: An ensemble method that creates a ‘forest’ of decision trees and merges their outputs to improve accuracy and control over-fitting.
ML - Supervised - Classification - Suppo: Support Vector Machines (SVM): SVMs find the hyperplane that best divides a dataset into classes. It is effective in high-dimensional spaces.
ML - Supervised - Regression: Regression tasks involve predicting a continuous value. Examples include predicting house prices, stock market prices, and other continuous variables.
ML - Supervised - Regression - LinearReg: It models the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables using a straight line.
ML - Supervised - Regression - RidgeRegr: A type of linear regression that includes a regularization term to prevent over-fitting.
ML - Supervised - Regression - LassoRegr: Similar to ridge regression but can produce sparse models with fewer variables.
ML - Unsupervised: Unsupervised learning involves training a model on data without labeled responses. The system tries to learn the patterns and the structure from the input data.
ML - Unsupervised - Clustering: Clustering involves grouping a set of objects in such a way that objects in the same group are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.
ML - Unsupervised - Clustering - KMeansC: One of the simplest and most popular clustering algorithms. It partitions the dataset into K clusters where each data point belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean.
ML - Unsupervised - Clustering - Hierarc: Builds a tree of clusters. The algorithm can be agglomerative (“bottom-up”) or divisive (“top-down”).
ML - Unsupervised - Association: Association learning is used to find interesting relationships or patterns between variables in large datasets.
ML - Unsupervised - Association - Aprior: Often used in market basket analysis to find associations between items in large datasets.
ML - Unsupervised - Association - EclatA: Another algorithm for finding frequent item sets, it is faster than the Apriori algorithm in many cases.
ML - Unsupervised - DimensionalReduction: Dimensionality reduction techniques are used to reduce the number of random variables under consideration by obtaining a set of principal variables.
Principal Component Analysis (PCA): Transforms the data into a set of linearly uncorrelated variables called principal components.
t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE): A technique for dimensionality reduction that is particularly well suited for the visualization of high-dimensional datasets.
ML - SemiSupervised: Semi-supervised learning falls between supervised and unsupervised learning. It uses both labeled and unlabeled data for training. Typically, a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data are used. This approach can significantly improve learning accuracy.
ML - Reinforced: Reinforcement learning is an area of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by performing certain actions and observing the rewards/results of those actions. It is often described using the concept of states, actions, and rewards.
ML - Reinforced - Concepts - State: The current situation of the agent.
ML - Reinforced - Concepts - Reward: The feedback from the environment based on the action taken by the agent.
ML - Reinforced - Algorithms - QLearning: A value-based method that seeks to find the best action to take given the current state.
ML - Reinforced - Algorithms - DeepQ-Net: Deep Q-Networks (DQN): Uses a neural network to approximate the Q-value function.
ML - Reinforced - Algorithms - PolicyGra: Directly optimizes the policy by maximizing the expected reward.
ML - DeepLearning - 2010: Deep learning is a subset of machine learning that involves neural networks with many layers. These deep neural networks are capable of learning from large amounts of data.
ML - NeuralNetworks: ‍A neural network comes one layer down from machine learning: it describes a machine learning model that mimics the decision-making process of the human brain by simulating how biological neurons work together to recognize patterns, evaluate options, and draw conclusions.A neural network is composed of three layers of neuron-like ‘nodes’: the input layer, the hidden layer, and the output layer.
ML - NeuralNetworks - CNN: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) Primarily used for image data. CNNs use convolutional layers to filter inputs for useful information.
ML - NeuralNetworks - RNN: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) Designed for sequential data. RNNs have connections that form directed cycles, allowing information to persist.
ML - NeuralNetworks - LSTM: Long Short-Term Memory Networks (LSTMs) A type of RNN that can learn long-term dependencies. They are well-suited for time-series forecasting and natural language processing.
ML - NeuralNetworks - GAN: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) Consist of two neural networks, a generator and a discriminator, that compete with each other to create realistic data.
ML - EnsembleLearning: Ensemble learning methods use multiple learning algorithms to obtain better predictive performance than could be obtained from any of the constituent learning algorithms alone.
ML - EnsembleLearning - Methods - Baggin: Bagging, or Bootstrap Aggregating, aims to reduce the variance of a model by generating additional data for training from the dataset using combinations with repetitions to produce multi-sets of the original data. Random Forests: An example of a bagging technique where multiple decision trees are created and the results are averaged.
ML - EnsembleLearning - Methods - Boosti: Boosting aims to create a strong classifier from a number of weak classifiers. It works by training the weak models sequentially, each trying to correct its predecessor.
Each subsequent model attempts to correct the errors of the previous model.
Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM): Builds models sequentially and each new model corrects the residual errors of the combined ensemble of previous models.
An optimized distributed gradient boosting library designed to be highly efficient, flexible, and portable.
ML - TransferLearning: Transfer learning is a machine learning technique where a model developed for a particular task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task. This is particularly useful in deep learning where training a model can be resource-intensive.
GenerativeAI: Generative AI is a type of deep learning that focuses on creating new content, such as text, images, audio, video, or code, by learning patterns and structures from existing data - for example DALL-E 3 is the most well-known model used for image creation. Generative AI refers to models that can create new content, such as text, images, or music, based on patterns learned from vast datasets.
GenerativeAI - Prompt: The information, sentences, or questions that you enter into a Generative AI tool. An AI prompt is the input given to a large language model via a generative AI platform
GenerativeAI - Tools - LangChain: LangChain specializes in workflow orchestration, making it ideal for complex multi-step processes that chain together multiple LLM operations. It excels in applications requiring tool/API integrations, agent-based systems with reasoning capabilities, and scenarios needing extensive prompt engineering. LangChain also provides frameworks for evaluation and comparison of different approaches.
GenerativeAI - Tools - LlamaIndex: LlamaIndex focuses on document processing and data retrieval. Its strengths lie in handling complex document ingestion, advanced indexing of knowledge bases, and providing structured data access for LLMs. LlamaIndex is particularly valuable for customizing retrieval strategies, processing diverse document formats, and implementing query transformations and routing.
GenerativeAI - Tools - Generator - Image: text-to-image models developed by OpenAI using deep learning methodologies to generate digital images from natural language descriptions known as prompts.
GenerativeAI - LLMs: Large language models (LLMs) are a form of generative AI that focus on producing text.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP: MCP stands for Model Context Protocol, and it’s essentially a universal connector for AI applications. MCP is poised to become the standard for Al integration. MCP acts as a bridge between reasoning engines (like LLMs) and function executors (like custom APIs). Think of it as the USB-C of the AI world, allowing different AI tools and models to interact seamlessly with various data sources. With MCP, developers can focus on building innovative applications instead of spending time on complex integrations. allowing LLMs to easily access external data and tools, thereby enhancing their capabilities.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP - MCPHosts: Applications that need contextual AI capabilities, such as chatbots or IDEs.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP - MCPClients: These maintain a one-on-one connection with MCP servers and handle protocol specifics.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP - MCPServers: Lightweight programs that expose specific capabilities through the MCP interface, connecting to local or remote data sources.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP - LocalDataSou: Files and databases that MCP servers can securely access.
GenerativeAI - LLMs - MCP - RemoteServic: External services available over the Internet that MCP servers can connect to.
PredictiveAI: Predictive AI goes beyond simply predicting outcomes; it recommends optimal actions or decisions based on complex data analysis and optimization algorithms.
RAG: RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generator) are based on NLP technique to combine rule based output from the LLM itself. This technique is a step further from LLM making your product more customized based on your requirement (can be dashboards, user stories, etc.) E.g. hashtag#Chatbot hashtag#Midjourney content generators, text to speech converter are a few examples
RAG - Features - autonomy: Limited autonomy with static retrieval and predefined responses.
RAG - Features - learning: It does not adapt or learn over time. It retrieves and generates responses based on pre-trained models,
RAG _ UseCase: Static content creation, Q&A, and structured knowledge bases.
AIAgents - Features - core: A step up from RAG. Can execute tasks dynamically with minimal intervention.
AIAgents - Features - autonomy: High autonomy adapting to tasks with minimal intervention.
AIAgents - Features - learning: Learn based on agent type and input data.
AIAgents - A2A: Agent-to-Agent Protocol by Google. AI agents connect to each other. A2A focuses on how different AI agents talk to each other, no matter which company or framework they come from. It’s like giving AI agents a shared language so they can collaborate, delegate tasks, and work as a team. This is horizontal integration, connecting agents to other agents.
AIAgents - MCP: Model Context Protocol by Anthropic. AI agent connects to tools
AIAgents - ReactAgent: ReactAgent is an experimental autonomous agent that uses GPT-4 language model to generate and compose React components from user stories. It is built with React, TailwindCSS, Typescript, Radix UI, Shandcn UI, and OpenAI API.
AgenticAI: Agentic AI is an emerging field that leverages an array of different AI techniques to enable an ‘agent’ to tackle complex tasks autonomously - without human intervention. To do so, it combines the reasoning power of an LLM with an array of tools it can use to perceive and interact with its environment, as well as ML techniques like reinforcement learning. Agents represent the next real step forward in the field of AI
AgenticAI - Features - core: Combines retrieval, generation and dynamic actions.
AgenticAI - Features - autonomy: Very high autonomy combining self-learning and decision making.
AgenticAI - Workflow - Perception: The agent observes its environment using sensors or inputs (text, APIs, context, tools).
AgenticAI - Workflow - Brain: It processes observations via a core LLM, enhanced with memory, planning, and retrieval components.
AgenticAI - Workflow - Action: It executes a task, invokes a tool, or responds — influencing the environment.
AgenticAI - Workflow - Learning: (Implicit or Explicit) – Feedback is integrated to improve future decisions.
AgenticAI - Examples - SelfDrivingCars: One of the most exciting uses of Agentic AI is in autonomous vehicles. These AI systems perceive their surroundings, make driving decisions, and learn from every trip. Over time, they get better at navigating and handling new challenges on the road. For example, Tesla’s Full Self-Driving system is an example of Agentic AI that continuously learns from the driving environment and adjusts its behavior to improve safety and efficiency.
